aloe-vera-powder.name: Aloe vera powder (200:1)
aloe-vera-powder.description: Concentrated Aloe barbadensis leaf juice powder (200:1). Moisturizing, anti-inflammatory. Low anthraquinone content (<50 ppm).

sourcing.productionMethod: Aloe leaf gel concentrated and spray-dried or freeze-dried to powder form.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Mexico and Dominican Republic are major exporters. Most commercial aloe is cultivated, not wild-harvested.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Most aloe is plantation-grown with relatively low environmental impact. Wild harvesting is rare for commercial products.

apricot-shell-powder.name: Apricot shell powder
apricot-shell-powder.description: Finely ground Prunus armeniaca seed shells. Particle size 10-177 microns.

sourcing.productionMethod: Ground from apricot pit shells, a byproduct of apricot fruit and kernel oil processing.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Waste stream product from food industry. Turkey is the world's largest apricot producer.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Low-impact byproduct of fruit processing industry. Upcycled agricultural waste with minimal additional environmental footprint.

references.section: Apricot Kernel: Bioactivity, Characterization, Applications, and Health Attributes

buttermilk-powder.name: Buttermilk powder
buttermilk-powder.description: Dried cultured buttermilk. Creates creamy lather. Lactic acid provides gentle exfoliation.

sourcing.productionMethod: Spray-dried buttermilk, a byproduct of butter churning.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Byproduct of butter production. Major dairy regions have established supply chains.

environmental: Water and land use for cattle feed
ethicalConcerns.notes: Byproduct of butter production. Environmental impact tied to broader dairy industry. Organic and pasture-raised certifications indicate higher animal welfare standards.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Bovine Milk Proteins and Protein Derivatives as Used in Cosmetics

coffee-grounds.name: Coffee grounds (used)
coffee-grounds.description: Spent Coffea arabica grounds. Used grounds preferred - softer, less colour bleed. Dry thoroughly before adding at trace.

sourcing.productionMethod: Spent grounds from coffee brewing, dried and processed.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Typically upcycled waste from coffee consumption. Brazil produces ~35% of world coffee supply.

environmental: Coffee cultivation linked to deforestation in some regions
Pesticide and agrochemical use in conventional farming
social: Fair wage concerns for smallholder farmers
ethicalConcerns.notes: While used grounds are upcycled waste, the broader coffee industry has significant sustainability concerns. Fair Trade and Rainforest Alliance certifications address labour and environmental practices.

references.section: Coffea arabica: An Emerging Active Ingredient in Dermato-Cosmetic Applications

colloidal-oatmeal.name: Colloidal oatmeal
colloidal-oatmeal.description: Finely ground Avena sativa. Recognized skin protectant with monograph in European Pharmacopoeia. Add at trace. Particle size under 100 micrometers.

sourcing.productionMethod: Oat groats (Avena sativa) dehulled and finely milled to colloidal particle size.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Major grain crop with established global supply chains. Russia and Canada are top producers.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Oats are a low-impact staple crop with well-established agricultural practices. Generally considered sustainable with minimal ethical concerns.

references.section: Safety and efficacy of personal care products containing colloidal oatmeal

goat-milk-powder.name: Goat milk powder
goat-milk-powder.description: Full-cream powder from Capra aegagrus hircus. Rich in vitamins A, B6, B12, E. Reconstitute 8:1 water:powder.

sourcing.productionMethod: Fresh goat milk spray-dried to powder form.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: France and Netherlands are major European producers. Small-scale goat farming is common globally.

environmental: Livestock greenhouse gas emissions (lower than cattle)
ethicalConcerns.notes: Goat dairy has lower environmental impact than cow dairy per unit. Often produced on small family farms. Animal welfare certifications available for verified humane practices.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Bovine Milk Proteins and Protein Derivatives as Used in Cosmetics

jojoba-oil.name: Jojoba oil
jojoba-oil.description: Liquid wax ester (~97%) from Simmondsia chinensis seeds. Does not saponify. Add at trace as superfat for conditioning and stability.

sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Desert shrub cultivation. Arizona is the historical center of production. Argentina has expanded significantly.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Jojoba is a drought-resistant desert crop requiring minimal water and no irrigation in some regions. Replaced sperm whale oil in cosmetics, providing conservation benefit. Generally sustainable with low environmental impact.

references.section: Jojoba Oil: An Updated Comprehensive Review on Chemistry, Pharmaceutical Uses, and Toxicity

lanolin.name: Lanolin (anhydrous)
lanolin.description: Wool wax from sheep (Ovis aries). Creates protective barrier. Add at trace or as superfat. May cause sensitivity in some users.

sourcing.productionMethod: Extracted from raw sheep wool during scouring process, then refined and purified.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Byproduct of wool production. Australia is the world's largest wool producer.

environmental: Sheep farming land use and emissions
social: Mulesing practice in Australian sheep (surgical skin removal without anaesthesia)
ethicalConcerns.notes: Mulesing is a controversial practice in Australian wool production involving surgical removal of skin to prevent flystrike. ZQ Merino and Responsible Wool Standard certifications prohibit mulesing. New Zealand has largely phased out mulesing. Specify non-mulesed sources for ethical sourcing.

poppy-seeds.name: Poppy seeds
poppy-seeds.description: Whole seeds from Papaver somniferum. Does not create micro-tears.

sourcing.productionMethod: Harvested from mature Papaver somniferum seed pods, cleaned and processed for food-grade use.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Turkey is the largest legal exporter. Seeds must be properly washed to remove alkaloid residue for food/cosmetic use.

political: Papaver somniferum cultivation is regulated or prohibited in many countries
Legal cultivation requires government licensing in most regions
ethicalConcerns.notes: Opium poppy cultivation is heavily regulated internationally. Culinary poppy seeds are legal and widely available, but cultivation restrictions exist in many jurisdictions. Seeds for cosmetic use should be from licensed, food-grade sources.

pumice-powder.name: Pumice powder (fine)
pumice-powder.description: Volcanic rock powder (amorphous aluminum silicate). 80-200 mesh size. Non-crystalline structure, no respirable silite.

sourcing.productionMethod: Mined volcanic rock deposits, crushed and graded to particle size.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: United States production centered in Oregon and Arizona. Natural volcanic deposits are abundant globally.

environmental: Mining operations cause localized habitat disruption
ethicalConcerns.notes: Pumice is a naturally abundant volcanic mineral. Mining impact is generally localized and moderate. No significant labour or political concerns associated with pumice extraction.

sea-salt-fine.name: Sea salt (fine grain)
sea-salt-fine.description: Fine-grain sea salt. Rich in minerals (magnesium, calcium, potassium). Above 3% may inhibit lather.

sourcing.productionMethod: Solar evaporation of seawater or brine, or mined from ancient sea deposits.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Production methods vary by region. Fleur de sel and Celtic sea salt from France command premium prices.

environmental: Microplastic contamination documented in sea salt globally
Large-scale salt evaporation ponds can impact coastal ecosystems
ethicalConcerns.notes: Studies have found microplastics in sea salt from marine pollution. Rock salt (mined from ancient deposits) avoids this concern. Artisanal sea salt from protected coastal areas may have lower contamination.
